body.value: VIDEOS TO COME x 3: John Sheridan;  Richard Bell (brother was killed by IRA) and Anthony + Marie O’Reilly (sister was killed by loyalists); and Patrick Horner (who lives opposite the customs house).
FERMANAGH, Northern Ireland — John Sheridan stood ankle deep in the lush grass of his farm tracing the border between the U.K. and the Republic of Ireland with his finger.
"I'm being shoved back into a corner," he said, following the line in a 270-degree arc.
"That boy there," he said, waving in the direction of his 22-year-old son, Chris. "He doesn’t remember what it was like when there was a border."
The soldiers, the searches, the checkpoints needing to be traversed to enter local towns, the feeling you're living in a militarized zone. "It was soul destroying," Sheridan recalled.
Like many in Northern Ireland -- which is part of the U.K. — and the neighbouring Irish Republic — an independent country -- Sheridan is adamant that Britain’s looming exit...
That’s the hope: to preserve Deal — just as other coastal communities are weighing their own futures in a world where the climate is unmistakably changing.
test test TEST2 — more for the test.
But the "for sale" signs are cropping up - TEST4
